SEARCH
Package uk.ac.leedsbeckett.oop

Class Locomotive

java.lang.Object
uk.ac.leedsbeckett.oop.Vehicle
uk.ac.leedsbeckett.oop.Locomotive
public class Locomotive extends Vehicle
A locomotive that can move along railway tracks and pull carriages.

This is a CONCRETE CLASS (not abstract) - you can create Locomotive objects directly. It extends (inherits from) the Vehicle class, which means it gets all the fields and methods from Vehicle, plus adds its own locomotive-specific behavior.

What is Inheritance?

Locomotive "extends" Vehicle, which means:

  • Locomotive IS-A Vehicle (inheritance relationship)
  • Locomotive inherits all Vehicle's methods and fields
  • Locomotive can add new methods (like start() and stop())
  • Locomotive can override methods (like tick()) to change behavior

Key Features:

  • Can be started and stopped (running state)
  • Moves automatically when running
  • Handles corners and junctions automatically
  • Supports forward and reverse movement
  • Can pull carriages in a train formation
  • Detects collisions with other vehicles
  • Stops when encountering red signals
See Also:
  • Vehicle
  • Carriage

  • Constructor Details

    • Locomotive

      public Locomotive(GameWorld world, Position pos, Orientation orientation)
      Creates a new locomotive at the specified position on the railway.

      This is a CONSTRUCTOR - it's called when you create a new Locomotive object using "new Locomotive(...)". It calls the parent class (Vehicle) constructor using "super(...)" to initialize common vehicle fields.

      Example usage: 

       Locomotive loco = new Locomotive(world, new Position(5, 5), Orientation.EAST);

      Parameters:
      world - the game world containing the railway tracks, signals, and other objects
      pos - the initial grid position where the locomotive will be placed (must be on a valid track)
      orientation - the initial direction the locomotive is facing (NORTH, SOUTH, EAST, or WEST)
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the position is not on a track or if the track is incompatible with the orientation

  • Method Details

    • setAnimationStepPixels

      public void setAnimationStepPixels(int stepPixels)
      Sets the animation step size in pixels for this locomotive.

      This controls how fast the locomotive moves and in which direction:

      • Positive value: locomotive moves forward (in the direction it's facing)
      • Negative value: locomotive moves in reverse (backward)
      • Larger absolute value: locomotive moves faster
      • Smaller absolute value: locomotive moves slower

      Example: setAnimationStepPixels(16) makes the locomotive move twice as fast as the default (8 pixels).

      Parameters:
      stepPixels - the number of pixels to move each tick (must be non-zero)
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if stepPixels is 0 (would cause the locomotive to not move)

    • getAnimationStepPixels

      public int getAnimationStepPixels()
      Gets the current animation step size.

      This is a GETTER method - it simply returns the value of the animationStepPixels field.

      Returns:
      the number of pixels moved each tick (positive=forward, negative=reverse)

    • start

      public void start()
      Starts the locomotive moving along the tracks.

      After calling this method, the locomotive will move automatically each tick until stop() is called. The locomotive follows the tracks, automatically navigating corners and junctions.

      Example usage: 

       locomotive.start();  // Locomotive starts moving
 // ... locomotive moves for a while ...
 locomotive.stop();   // Locomotive stops

    • stop

      public void stop()
      Stops the locomotive.

      After calling this method, the locomotive will stop moving but will remain at its current position on the track. You can call start() again to make it resume moving.

    • isRunning

      public boolean isRunning()
      Checks if the locomotive is currently running.

      This is a GETTER method that tells you whether the locomotive is moving.

      Returns:
      true if the locomotive is running (moving), false if it is stopped

    • getAttachedCarriages

      public List<Carriage> getAttachedCarriages()
      Gets a list of all carriages attached to this locomotive.

      This method walks through the chain of attached vehicles and collects all the Carriage objects. If the locomotive has no carriages, it returns an empty list.

      How it works:

      1. Start with the first attached vehicle
      2. If it's a Carriage, add it to the list
      3. Move to the next attached vehicle
      4. Repeat until we reach the end of the chain
      Returns:
      an unmodifiable list of all carriages attached to this locomotive (empty if no carriages)

    • detachCarriage

      public boolean detachCarriage(Carriage c)
      Detaches a specific carriage from this locomotive.

      This method searches through the chain of attached vehicles looking for the specified carriage. If found, it breaks the attachment link.

      Note: If the carriage is in the middle of a chain, this will also detach all carriages behind it.

      Parameters:
      c - the carriage to detach from this locomotive
      Returns:
      true if the carriage was found and successfully detached, false if the carriage was not attached

    • tick

      public void tick()
      Called each game tick to update the locomotive state.

      This is a METHOD OVERRIDE - it replaces the tick() method from the Vehicle class with locomotive-specific behavior. The @Override annotation tells Java we're intentionally replacing the parent method.

      What this method does each tick:

      1. If the locomotive is running and not derailed, move it along the track
      2. Propagate the tick to any attached vehicles (so they update too)
      3. Enforce coupling to keep carriages following smoothly
      Overrides:
      tick in class Vehicle

    • stepTowards

      public boolean stepTowards(Position nextCell, int deltaPixels)
      Moves the locomotive toward a specific adjacent cell by a specified number of pixels.

      This method is used for controlled movement toward a specific neighboring cell. It checks if the movement is valid BEFORE changing the orientation, preventing the locomotive from visually rotating if the move will fail.

      Validation checks:

      1. Is the next cell actually adjacent (Manhattan distance of 1)?
      2. Is there track at both current and next cells?
      3. Do the tracks connect in the required direction?
      Parameters:
      nextCell - the adjacent cell to move towards (must be exactly one cell away horizontally or vertically)
      deltaPixels - the number of pixels to move toward that cell
      Returns:
      true if the locomotive moved (either changed position or pixel offset), false if movement was blocked
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if nextCell is not adjacent to the current cell
